statement.p: Let U be a 3 \times 3 matrix with U^T U=I and R be a region in \R^3 of volume 1. What is the volume of U(R), the image of R under the transformation U?

ol.li: The volume of the parallelepiped is the absolute value of the determinant, which in this case is 1.
Since the origin is a vertex, the volume is one sixth of the volume of the parallelogram spanned by (1, -1, 1), (3, 1, -1), (1, 3, 0), which is \dfrac{1}{6}\det(\mat{1 3 1;-1 1 3;1 -1 0}) = 2.

The volume is one sixth of the volume of the parallelogram spanned by (0, -2, 1) - (-1, -1, 0) = (1, -1, 1), (2, 0, -1) - (-1, -1, 0) = (3, 1, -1), (0, 2, 0) - (-1, -1, 0) = (1, 3, 0). The parallelogram is the same as the one in the previous problem. Therefore the volumn of the tetrahedron is still 2.
